verses.text: Then Jesus said to the crowds and to His disciples:
verses.comment: Jesus addresses both the crowd and the disciples together, indicating that His teaching is intended for all to hear. Compare with Luke 11:37.

verses.text: “The scribes and the Pharisees sit on Moses’ seat.
verses.comment: Moses' seat represented authoritative teaching. Jesus recognizes their authority based on succession from Moses himself, which hints at the idea of an ongoing leadership structure in God's people.

verses.text: So do and observe everything they tell you, but do not do as they do. For they preach, but do not practice.
verses.comment: Jesus tells the crowds to respect legitimate authority while warning against hypocrisy. Showing respect for religious authority even when its representatives are imperfect anticipates the later Christian emphasis on obedience to those in spiritual leadership unless they directly contradict God's commands.

verses.text: They tie up heavy burdens, hard to bear, and lay them on people’s shoulders, but they themselves are unwilling to move them with their finger.
verses.comment: The religious leaders enforce strict rituals and laws that are hard for ordinary people, while not helping them. See also the Jerusalem Council in Acts 15, which addresses unnecessary burdens in the church.

verses.text: They do all their deeds to be seen by others. For they make their phylacteries broad and the fringes of their garments long.
verses.comment: External displays of piety are rebuked by Jesus, emphasizing the need for authentic devotion. He refers to traditional Jewish symbols, but criticizes their use simply for show.

verses.text: They love the place of honor at feasts and the best seats in the synagogues,
verses.comment: Desiring high status and recognition is a sign of pride, contrary to the humility Jesus teaches.

verses.text: and greetings in the marketplaces, and to be called ‘Rabbi’ by others.
verses.comment: Titles of prestige are sought by the proud, but Jesus will soon contrast this with the proper attitude of His followers.

verses.text: But you are not to be called ‘Rabbi,’ for you have one Teacher, and you are all brothers.
verses.comment: Jesus teaches about radical equality among His disciples. Only Christ is the true Teacher. Spiritually, this highlights the unity and humility called for in true Christian community.

verses.text: And do not call anyone on earth your father, for you have one Father, who is in heaven.
verses.comment: This teaching addresses spiritual pride, not literal prohibitions about the word 'father.' In the rest of Scripture, spiritual fatherhood is affirmed, as Paul calls himself a father to his converts (1 Corinthians 4:15). Jesus' point is about ultimate spiritual authority belonging to God alone.

verses.text: Neither are you to be called instructors, for you have one Instructor, the Christ.
verses.comment: Jesus emphasizes His own role as the unique divine teacher. "The Christ" indicates both His messianic office and His divinity, as instructor and Lord.

verses.text: The greatest among you shall be your servant.
verses.comment: True greatness in God's kingdom is measured by humble service, a core teaching constantly repeated by Jesus.

verses.text: Whoever exalts himself will be humbled, and whoever humbles himself will be exalted.
verses.comment: The spiritual principle of humility and exaltation echoes Proverbs 29:23; God honors those who humble themselves.

verses.text: But woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you shut the kingdom of heaven in people’s faces. For you do not enter yourselves, nor do you allow those who are trying to enter.
verses.comment: By their actions, these leaders block people from a relationship with God. Jesus warns of accountability for religious leaders who misuse their authority.

verses.text: [Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you devour widows’ houses and for a pretense make long prayers. Therefore you will receive the greater condemnation.]
verses.comment: This verse does not appear in some early manuscripts but is supported by parallels in Mark and Luke. It underscores the seriousness of hypocrisy, especially toward the vulnerable.

verses.text: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you travel over sea and land to make a single convert, and when he becomes one, you make him twice as much a child of hell as yourselves.
verses.comment: Jesus criticizes the leaders for focusing on outward conversions without teaching true righteousness; spiritual corruption is passed down with false teaching.

verses.text: Woe to you, blind guides, who say, ‘If anyone swears by the temple, it is nothing, but if anyone swears by the gold of the temple, he is bound by his oath.’
verses.comment: They distort oaths and prioritize material value over spiritual sanctity, missing the essence of God's law.

verses.text: You blind fools! For which is greater, the gold or the temple that has made the gold holy?
verses.comment: Jesus insists the temple—God’s dwelling—makes things holy, not the other way around. The distinction elevates spiritual over material.

verses.text: And you say, ‘If anyone swears by the altar, it is nothing, but if anyone swears by the gift that is on the altar, he is bound by his oath.’
verses.comment: A parallel error: value is placed on gifts more than the act of sacrifice itself, missing the spiritual core behind ritual.

verses.text: You blind men! For which is greater, the gift or the altar that makes the gift holy?
verses.comment: The altar sanctifies all offerings. This teaching also hints ahead to the New Testament understanding of the Eucharist, where the altar and the deeper meaning of sacrifice are fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: So whoever swears by the altar swears by it and by everything on it.
verses.comment: The spiritual reality of the altar encompasses all that involves it; thus, sincerity in vows is emphasized.

verses.text: And whoever swears by the temple swears by it and by Him who dwells in it.
verses.comment: God Himself dwells in the temple, highlighting the presence of God in the midst of His people.

verses.text: And whoever swears by heaven swears by the throne of God and by Him who sits upon it.
verses.comment: To swear by heaven is to involve God Himself, thus every oath has a profound sacred dimension.

verses.text: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you tithe mint, dill, and cumin, and have neglected the weightier matters of the law: justice, mercy, and faithfulness. These you ought to have done, without neglecting the others.
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the necessity of both ‘small’ and ‘large’ observances of God’s law but demands priorities rightly ordered—faithful action rooted in justice and mercy.

verses.text: You blind guides, straining out a gnat but swallowing a camel!
verses.comment: Hyperbolic language. They obsess over tiny details but miss the great commandments, revealing spiritual blindness.

verses.text: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you clean the outside of the cup and the plate, but inside they are full of greed and self-indulgence.
verses.comment: True purity originates from the heart, not mere external rituals. Links to Christ’s other rebukes of surface-level religion.

verses.text: You blind Pharisee! First clean the inside of the cup and the plate, so that the outside also may be clean.
verses.comment: Internal transformation—purity of heart—is the root for true righteousness.

verses.text: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you are like whitewashed tombs, which outwardly appear beautiful, but within are full of dead men’s bones and all uncleanness.
verses.comment: The focus is on spiritual death hidden by outward conformity. A dramatic picture drawn from Jewish burial customs before Passover.

verses.text: So you also outwardly appear righteous to others, but within you are full of hypocrisy and lawlessness.
verses.comment: True righteousness is not just external but must be grounded in the interior transformation by God’s grace.

verses.text: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you build the tombs of the prophets and decorate the monuments of the righteous,
verses.comment: They honor the prophets in death but rejected them in life, exposing deep inconsistency.

verses.text: and say, ‘If we had lived in the days of our fathers, we would not have taken part with them in shedding the blood of the prophets.’
verses.comment: A dangerous self-righteousness—failing to see their own complicity in persecuting God’s messengers.

verses.text: So you testify against yourselves that you are sons of those who murdered the prophets.
verses.comment: Acknowledgment of spiritual lineage—the same rebellious spirit continues in them.

verses.text: Fill up, then, the measure of your fathers.
verses.comment: A prophetic statement—Jesus foretells that their actions will soon culminate in His own death, fulfilling what their ancestors began.

verses.text: You serpents, you brood of vipers, how will you escape being sentenced to hell?
verses.comment: Strong language linking them to the serpent imagery, symbolizing rebellion and opposition to God since Genesis 3.

verses.text: Therefore I send you prophets and wise men and scribes, some of whom you will kill and crucify, and some you will flog in your synagogues and persecute from town to town,
verses.comment: Jesus prophesies the treatment of His messengers. "I send" is a divine statement: Jesus claims divine prerogative in sending messengers.

verses.text: so that on you may come all the righteous blood shed on earth, from the blood of righteous Abel to the blood of Zechariah the son of Berechiah, whom you murdered between the sanctuary and the altar.
verses.comment: This covers all Scripture, from Genesis to 2 Chronicles, the first and last books in the Hebrew canon. Jesus claims authority over salvation history. The mention of Abel and Zechariah forms ‘bookends’ of righteous martyrs.

verses.text: Truly, I say to you, all these things will come upon this generation.
verses.comment: "Truly, I say to you" is an authoritative pronouncement. Judgment comes as prophecy is fulfilled in the events following Jesus’ ministry.

verses.text: O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, the city that kills the prophets and stones those who are sent to her! How often I wished to gather your children together as a hen gathers her brood under her wings, but you were not willing!
verses.comment: Jesus reveals His divine compassion and longing to save Jerusalem; the motherly image points to God’s protective care for His people. His lament underscores His divinity and His deep desire for the unity of His people.

verses.text: See, your house is left to you desolate.
verses.comment: Prophetic announcement of judgment on Jerusalem and the temple. The word ‘house’ often refers to the temple, echoing Old Testament laments over destroyed sanctuaries.

verses.text: For I tell you, you will not see Me again until you say, ‘Blessed is He who comes in the Name of the Lord!’”
verses.comment: Jesus refers to His Second Coming and fulfillment of messianic prophecy. The use of ‘until’ hints at a time when all will come to recognize Him. Christ’s use of Psalm 118 reveals His messianic and divine authority.
